Chemistry Department, Yuncheng University, Yuncheng, Shanxi 044000, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) represents a pivotal reaction, with its resultant product is widely used in solvents, fuels, pesticides, pharmaceuticals and other fields. The challenge associated with this process resides in achieving high selective generation of GVL. In this work, a spherical flower-like ZnO supported Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst (NiCo/ZnO) was prepared to facilitate the process of LA to GVL. The results showed that the NiCo alloy formed in the catalyst enhance both the hydrogenation activity of LA and the selectivity of GVL. Furthermore, the Lewis basic sites (SLB) in ZnO are instrumental in activating the C = O group. More importantly, it was found that the ethanol solvent can combine with LA to form ethyl levulinate (EL) which was more easily hydrogenated than LA. By regulating the appropriate calcination temperature, the proportions of NiCo alloy and SLB can be adjusted, and the NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst with good performance was synthesized. Under the reaction condition of 100 °C and 2 MPa of H2 for 5 h, the LA was completely converted, yielding a remarkable GVL production of 99 %. The catalyst displayed good recyclability, maintaining its activity after 6 times without loss of activity, highlighting its potential for practical application in biomass conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selective hydrogenation Lewis basic sites NiCo/ZnO γ-Valerolactone Levulinic acid Data availability No 1 Introduction With the excessive exploitation of fossil fuels, the energy shortages and environmental pollution have become increasingly prominent, and it is urgent to find alternatives to fossil fuels. As the sole renewable resource that can fix carbon, biomass has advantages of large reserves, wide sources, and carbon-neutral utilization process, making it an ideal choice to replace fossil fuels [1]. Biomass can be converted into many platform molecules through a series of catalytic transformations [2,3]. In 2004, the US Department of Energy reported that levulinic acid (LA) is highlighted as one of the most promising five carbon sugar derivatives among 10 biomass platform molecules for future development and utilization, which promoted the research efforts focused on LA [4]. LA can produce various high value-added chemicals through different catalytic processes, such as γ-valerolactone (GVL) [5], diphenolic acid (DPA) [6], 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (MTHF) [7], various lipids and resins, etc. [8]. Among them, GVL has drawn considerable attention in the last decade because of its distinct physicochemical properties and promising application in fuel. GVL is a naturally existing, safe, biodegradable and nontoxic chemical, which can be utilized as the green solvent, seasoning, food ingredient, pharmaceutical intermediate, and fuel additive [9]. GVL can be synthesized by the hydrogenation of LA, following a two-step pathway that encompasses hydrogenation and dehydration. However, the debate over whether the reaction pathway involves hydrogenation followed by dehydration or vice versa remains ongoing [10]. Usually, the metal component of the catalyst initiates the hydrogenation of LA, while dehydration and cyclization are promoted by an acidic reaction environment [11]. In the catalytic hydrogenation of LA to GVL, two pivotal areas of research focus on the selection of hydrogen donor and design of catalyst, which significantly influences the yield of GVL and reaction pathways. The common hydrogen donors include H2 gas, alcohols, and formic acid. Due to the in-situ production of formic acid at equimolar concentrations with LA, it is considered a favorable resource [12]. But formic acid has strong corrosiveness and requires harsh reaction conditions and the use of stable catalysts. Alcohols are ideal green hydrogen donors and reaction solvents that can catalyze LA to obtain high GVL yields under mild conditions [13]. However, the addition of co-catalysts (such as KOH, triethylamine, etc.) during the reaction can easily cause environmental problems. H2 gas is the simplest and most commonly used hydrogen donor, but higher hydrogen pressures (>3 MPa) are often required during the reaction process [14]. Therefore, applying both hydrogen donors simultaneously to the LA hydrogenation reaction may produce unexpected results. In addition, the design of catalyst is also a key research direction. Extensive efforts have been made on noble metal (such as Ru, Pt, Pd, and Ir) catalysts for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL, with carbon-supported Ru catalysts being the most extensively used [15,16]. For example, Martinelli et al. [17]. used commercial Ru/C as the primary catalyst and Amberlyst A70 as co-catalyst to catalyze the selective hydrogenation of LA to GVL. The results showed that a 99 % GVL yield was obtained at 70 °C for 3 h under 3 MPa of H2. Zhang et al. [18] prepared a metal organic framework UiO-66 supported 0.85wt% Ru/ZrO2@C using a novel stable catalyst technology and compared its performance with that of commercial Ru/C in LA hydrogenation reaction. The results showed that both catalysts exhibited good LA activity and selectivity, but 0.85wt% Ru/ZrO2@C showed better catalyst stability. Han et al. [19] developed ultra-thin rutile TiO2 nanosheets decorated with quantum dot Ru (exposed 001 facet). Due to the enhanced interaction between the support and metal by the high-energy TiO2 (001) surface, the catalyst can catalyze the conversion of LA to GVL at room temperature with conversion and selectivity over 99 %. Although good activity and stability were obtained for noble metal catalysts, the high cost and availability limit its industrial application. To replacing the noble metals, non-noble metal (such as Ni, Cu, Co, Fe and Zr) catalysts have also been reported [20,21]. Among them, Ni and Co stands out as promising candidates for hydrogenation reaction due to their catalytic potential, durability, availability, and affordability. For example, Liu et al. introduced Ni-embedded hierarchically-porous carbon microspheres (Ni@NCMs) [22], which exhibited excellent activity and stability compared with commercial Ni/C catalyst, and 99 % yield was obtained at 200 °C for 4 h under 3 MPa H2. Li et al. reported a Co/Al2O3 catalyst that achieved a 99 % GVL yield at 180 °C for 3 h under 5 MPa H2. Due to the core-shell structure of Co/Al2O3 and the strong interaction between Co and Al, the catalyst exhibited good stability [23]. Besides, other supported Ni and Co-based catalysts were also reported, such as Ni/MgO-Al2O3, Ni/MMT, Co/ZrO2, Co/NC and so on [24–28]. However, the above monometallic catalysts usually need stringent reaction conditions to achieve high GVL yield, such as high temperature, high pressure, and long reaction time. In the LA hydrogenation reaction, bimetallic catalysts exhibited significant improvement due to their synergistic effect. For example, Gupta et al. developed a hydrotalcite-derived catalyst (Cu/Ni/Mg/Al) that achieved 100 % GVL yield at 140 °C for 3 h under 3 MPa of H2. The excellent reaction activity was attributed to the synergistic effect between Cu, Ni and MgO [29]. However, the currently reported bimetallic catalysts (such as Ni-Cu, Ni-Fe, Ni-Ru) still fall short of meeting industrial needs [30,31]. According to relevant literature [32], the formation of strong metal-support interaction in the catalyst can effectively regulate the reaction activity and selectivity and improve their stability for the hydrogenation reaction. In our recent reports [33], Ni-based catalyst supported on ZnO showed good catalytic performance for the hydrogenolysis of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF). The strong metal-support interaction between ZnO and Ni plays a crucial role in regulating the distribution of products and improve catalyst stability (9 cycles). Thus, using ZnO as a support offers distinct advantages for LA hydrogenation reaction. Besides, as an amphoteric oxide, ZnO has both basic and acidic sites, which may promote LA hydrogenation and dehydration, thereby efficiently synthesizing GVL. Herein, a series of ZnO supported Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts have been synthesized. The proportion of NiCo alloy and acid-base sites were adjusted through regulating the interaction between metal and support by varying the calculation temperature. The catalytic performance of these catalysts in the hydrogenation reaction of LA to GVL was thoroughly evaluated. Besides, the structure and morphology, reaction conditions (including reaction temperature, reaction solvent, reaction pressure and catalyst dosage) and recyclability of the catalyst were explored. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation All the supported catalysts were prepared by a simple co-precipitation method. Firstly, a mixed acidic solution of 0.012 mol/L Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99 %, Sigma Aldrich), 0.048 mol/L Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99 %, Sigma Aldrich), and 0.2285 mol/L Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (99 %, Sigma Aldrich) were prepared, and a 0.5 mol/L solution of (NH4)2CO3 (99 %, Sigma Aldrich) solution was prepared as the precipitant for later use. Secondly, a beaker with 1000 mL deionized water was placed into an 80 °C water bath and stir continuously. Then, the above mixed solutions were pumped into the beaker to initiate the precipitation reaction using a peristaltic pump (BT50S), and the pH of the solution was maintained at 7.0 using a pH meter (FE20 plus). After the reaction, the precipitated substances were aged for 2 h, filtered, washed, and dried at 120 °C for 8 h to obtain the catalyst precursor, and denoted as NiCo/ZnO-Pr. The above precursors were calcined at 300 °C, 400 °C, 500 °C, and 600 °C for 3 h, and the resulting oxidized samples were denoted as NiCoOx/ZnOCT (where CT represents calcination temperature). Finally, the oxidized sample was subjected to a H2 atmosphere at 400 °C (30 mL/min, 3 h) to obtain the final reduced catalyst, and denoted as NiCo/ZnOCT. The theory contents of Ni, Co and Zn were 3.18 wt%,12.78 wt% and 67.51wt%, respectively. Ni/ZnO, Co/ZnO and pure ZnO samples were prepared following the above same procedure used for NiCo/ZnOCT, but in the absence of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and/or Co(NO3)2·6H2O, respectively. NiCo/ZnOamo-400 (IMP) and NiCo/ZnO-400 (IMP) catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method and ZnOamo was commercially purchased ZnO. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was performed using TG/DTA7200 equipment. A sample of 10 mg was weighed and heated from room temperature up to 800 °C at a flow rate of 10 °C/min in an air atmosphere. X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) measurements were performed using the D8 Advance A25 X-ray powder diffractometer. Spectra were obtained using Cu Kα (154.06pm) operating at 40 kV tube voltage and 200 mA current. H2-TPR, NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD were performed using a TP-5080 instrument equipped with a TCD detector. Typically, samples (100 mg) were loaded in the middle of a quartz tube. Before reaction, samples were pretreated at 150 °C for 1 h under He atmosphere (30 mL/min) to remove impurities and moisture, and then the samples were cooled down to room temperature. H2-TPR process: Introduce a mixture of 10 % H2–90 % He (30 mL/min) and raise the temperature to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min for 0.5 h. The H2 consumption was recorded by the TCD signal. NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD process: Pure NH3 (CO2) was introduced at room temperature for adsorption for 1 h, and the carrier (He, 30 mL/min) was switched for blowing for 1 h. Then, the temperature was raised from room temperature to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, and the TCD signal was recorded during the heating process. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) was performed using JSM-7001F instrument with a resolution of 1 nm and an acceleration voltage of 10 kV. High-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) was recorded on a JEM-2100F instrument with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the samples were carried out on the JWGB instruments. The specific surface areas were calculated with the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using Thermo Fisher Scientif K-Alpha spectrometre, equipped with a monochromatic X-ray source. Spectra were obtained using an aluminum anode (Al Kα=1486.6 eV) with a vacuum degree below 3 × 10–8 Pa and calibrated at C 1 s (284.6 eV). The data processing was fitted using XPSPEAK Version 4.1 software. 2.3 Catalytic hydrogenation of LA Catalytic hydrogenation of LA to GVL was performed in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave. In a typical reaction, 1 mmol of LA (0.116 g), 50 mg of toluene (internal standard), an appropriate amount of catalyst, and 10 mL of solvent were respectively weighed and loaded into the autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and purged ten times with H2 and then the reaction was conducted at designed temperature and pressure under continuous stirring (400 rpm). After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature. The catalyst was separated by centrifugation and the reaction products were subjected to GC and GC–MS analysis. In all cases, the carbon balances were calculated at about 96 %. After the reaction, the recycled catalyst was washed and dried at 60 °C under vacuum for the next run. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of precursor and calcined NiCoOx/ZnO-CT samples Firstly, the thermal decomposition characteristics were studied by TG technology. As illustrated in Fig. S1, within the temperature range of 50–100 °C, a slight weight loss was observed, attributing to the desorption of surface-adsorbed water. When the temperature was about 220 °C, the precursor began to undergo a significant weight loss, with the maximum weight loss rate occurring at around 300 °C. When the temperature exceeded 310 °C, there was almost no weight loss. The above results indicate that the thermal decomposition of the precursor is a simple and one-step process, which accords with the decomposition characteristics of basic carbonates. XRD patterns of the catalyst precursor and calcined NiCoOx/ZnOCT samples at different temperatures (300 °C, 400 °C, 500 °C and 600 °C) were shown in Fig. 1 . Fig 1a revealed that the diffraction peaks at 13.2°, 28.2°, 33.0° and 36.2° were belong to xZnCO3∙yZn(OH)∙zH2O (JCPDF 00–019–1458) and the diffraction peaks at 24.3°, 34.8°, 59,8° and 31.2° were belong to xNiCO3∙yZn(OH)∙zH2O and xCoCO3∙yZn(OH)∙zH2O, respectively (JCPDF 00–035–0501 and JCPDF 00–048–0083) [34], as also corroborated by TG analysis. From Fig. 1b-e, the peaks at 31.5°, 34.5°, 36.4°, 47.5°, 56.7°, 62.8° and 67.8° were attributed to ZnO (JCPDF 00–036–1451) for all calcined samples and with elevating of calcination temperature from 300 °C to 600 °C, the peak intensity of ZnO gradually increased. The diffraction peaks at 19.0°, 31.3°, 36.8°, 44.7°, 55.6°, 59.3°, 65.1° and 38.1° were belong to CoZn2O4 (JCPDF 00–023–1309) and no other Co oxide species were observed, indicating the presence of interaction between Co and ZnO [34]. Besides, NiCo2O4 (JCPDF 00–020–0781) was formed and strengthened at 2θ=38.3°, and no free Ni oxide species were observed, indicating an interaction between Ni and Co [35]. The above results underscored an interaction between Ni, Co and ZnO, with the interaction strengthening as the calcination temperature rises. The reducibility and interaction characteristics of the NiCoOx/ZnOCT samples were studied by H2-TPR analysis (Fig. 2 and Fig.S2). In Fig. 2a, the NiCoOx/ZnO-300 sample exhibited two prominent reduction peaks corresponding to Co oxide species (CoZn2O4), whereas no distinct peak for Ni oxide species was observed, potentially due to the Ni peak being obscured by the Co peak. In Fig. 2b, two reduction peaks of Co oxide species for NiCoOx/ZnO-400 sample shifted towards higher temperature, indicating a strengthened interaction between Co and ZnO. It was worth noting that a weak tail peak signal observed at about 500–700 °C can be attributed to the Zn2+in ZnO reduction to Zn0 due to hydrogen spillover from the metallic Ni and/or Co to ZnO, which also confirmed the existence of a strong metal-support interaction, aligning with our previous work [36] and supported by related work by Wang and Tang et al. [34,37]. In Fig. 2c-d, in addition to the peaks of Co oxide species, which continued to shift toward higher temperature with elevating of calcination temperature from 500 °C to 600 °C, a new H2 reduction peak was detected in the range of 375–410 °C, which was attributed to the reduction of NiCo2O4 to NiCo alloy, as revealed by XRD patterns. To further confirm the existence of the interaction between Ni and Co, NiO/ZnO, CoOx/ZnO and NiCoOx/ZnO samples calcined at 400 °C were compared in Fig.S2. According to the literature [38], the reduction peak at about 320 °C corresponded to free NiO. There was only one peak located at 460 °C for NiO/ZnO due to the strong interaction between NiO and ZnO. For the reduction profile of CoOx/ZnO, two reduction peaks located at 280 °C and 450 °C were observed, corresponding to the reduction of Co species in CoZn2O4. For the reduction profile of NiCoOx/ZnO-400, the reduction peaks shifted towards lower temperature, which could be attributed to the synergistic effect between Ni and Co species, facilitating the reduction of Co oxide species. The above results indicated that there was an interaction between Ni, Co, and ZnO that can be adjusted by regulating calcination temperature. The micro-morphology of calcined NiCoOx/ZnOCT samples was examined by SEM images presented in Fig. 3 . Fig. 3A(1–2) depicted the low/high-magnification SEM images of the samples calcined at 300 °C. It was observed that NiCoOx/ZnO-300 mainly exhibited the spherical flower-like particles (5–10 μm) composed of multiple thin-flakes inside. In Fig. 3B(1–2), it was observed that the flower-like morphology can be maintained for NiCoOx/ZnO-400. In Fig. 3C(1–2), as the calcination temperature was increased to 500 °C, it can be seen that the thin flakes inside of the flower-like particles gradually thickened and aggregated, indicating the gradual sintering for NiCoOx/ZnO-500. In Fig. 3D(1–2), it can be seen that the flakes inside undergone significant changes, indicating severe sintering for NiCoOx/ZnO-600. 3.2 Characterization of reduced NiCo/ZnO-CT catalysts Fig. 4 showed XRD patterns of the reduced NiCo/ZnOCT catalysts. After reducing the above calcined samples at 400 °C, it was notable that while the diffraction peaks of ZnO remained present, the diffraction peaks of CoZn2O4 and NiCo2O4 disappeared, indicating that the calcined samples have been completely reduced. The diffraction peaks at 44.4° and 51.7° were attributed to NiCo alloy [39,40], and compared with the standard cards Ni (JCPDF 00–004–0850) and Co (JCPDF 00–015–0806), no characteristic diffraction peaks of metal Ni and Co were detected, which indicated that NiCo alloy was the main form of existence after reduction. According to the Scherrer equation, the crystal sizes of ZnO and NiCo alloy were calculated based on the half-peak width of the characteristic peaks at 2θ=36.3° and 2θ= 44.4°. The crystal sizes of ZnO were 9.7, 11.6, 19.8 and 25.4 nm, and the crystal sizes of NiCo alloy were 3.9, 4.5, 7.4 and 10.6 nm (Table 1 ). The above results showed that when the calcination temperature was low (300 °C and 400 °C), the crystal sizes of reduced catalysts were small. However, as the calcination temperature increased to 500 °C and 600 °C, the crystal sizes of the reduced catalysts were large due to the sintering at high temperature. The chemical composition and textural characteristics of the reduced NiCo/ZnOCT samples were summarized in Table 1. The actual metal content of the reduced catalysts aligns well with the theoretical content (Ni 3.18 wt%, Co 12.78 wt%, Zn 67.51 wt%). After reduction, both the BET surface area and pore volume decreased, while the pore size first increased and then decreased. The BET surface area, pore volume and pore size were 65.3 m2 g-1, 0.32 cm3 g-1 and 20.3 nm respectively for NiCo/ZnO-300 catalyst. When the calcination temperature was increased to 400 °C, the BET surface area and pore volume slightly decreased to 58.6 m2 g-1 and 0.25 cm3 g-1, respectively, while the pore size increased to 32.5 nm, which may be due to the changes in the dispersion and aggregation of particles. Further elevating the calcination temperature to 500 °C and 600 °C, the BET surface area, pore volume and pore size significantly decreased (19.4 m2 g-1, 0.11 cm3 g-1, 25.3 nm and 10.2 m2 g-1, 0.04 cm3 g-1, 17.8 nm), suggesting the occurrence of sintering. The morphology of the reduced NiCo/ZnOCT catalysts was investigated by SEM images (Fig. 5 ). When compared to the oxide samples in Fig. 3, there was no significant change in the morphology or particle sizes for the reduced NiCo/ZnOCT catalysts (Fig. 5A-D), which indicated that the flower-like particles can be well maintained in a H2 atmosphere at 400 °C. The distribution of composition elements for the reduced NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst was analyzed by SEM-EDS in Fig. 5E. It was observed that Ni, Co, Zn, and O were uniformly distributed in the catalyst, which may be due to the strong metal-support interaction, which enhanced the dispersibility of the active components Ni and Co. TEM analysis was used to investigate the geometric structure of the reduced NiCo/ZnOCT catalysts. From Fig. 6 A1-D1, it can be seen that the catalyst was composed of a large number of dispersed particles and a clear crystalline structure can be observed, The primary crystalline phase present was the NiCo alloy phase (111), with an interplanar spacing of d = 0.201∼0.204 nm, as also revealed by XRD and H2-TPR analysis, indicating that the NiCo/ZnOCT catalysts predominantly existed in the form of the NiCo alloy phase. From Fig. 6A(2–4) and Fig. 6B(2–4), it can be seen that the metal particles in NiCo/ZnO-300 and NiCo/ZnO-400 catalysts were evenly distributed, with particle sizes centered around 13–15 nm exhibiting a normal distribution. As the calcination temperature was increased to 500 °C in Fig. 6C(2–4), the agglomeration occurred, leading to an increase in particle size to 20–22 nm. Further increasing the temperature to 600 °C in Fig. 6D(2–4), the significant agglomeration occurred and the particle size increased to 45–47 nm, indicating serious sintering. XPS measurement of the reduced NiCo/ZnOCT catalysts was employed to investigate the electronic properties (Fig. 7 and Table 2 ). From the full-scan XPS spectrum in Fig. 7A, there were five signal peaks corresponding to C1 s, O 1 s, Co 2p, Ni 2p and Zn 2p in all reduced catalysts, respectively [41]. In the Co 2p pattern (Fig. 7B), the peaks at approximately 780.1 eV and 795.2 eV, corresponding to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, are assigned to metallic Co in the NiCo alloy. The peaks at about 781.2 eV and 796.8 eV were attributed to Co-O; while the two peaks at about 786.0 eV and 802.2 eV were assigned to the satellite peaks. In Ni 2p pattern (Fig. 7C), the peaks at 854.5 eV and 871.3 eV, representing Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2, respectively, are indicative of metallic Ni in the NiCo alloy. The peaks at about 855.8 eV and 873.2 eV were attributed to Ni-O; and the two peaks at about 861.5 eV and 879.7 eV were assigned to the satellite peaks. From Fig. 7, Co-O and Ni-O signals may originate from the oxidation of the metal on the catalyst surface after passivation by 1 %O2/99 %N2 in catalyst preparation process. This also explains why no obvious Co2+ or Ni2+ diffraction peaks were found in the XRD patterns (Fig. 4), but clear signals were observed in the XPS spectrum. In Zn 2p pattern (Fig. 7D), the Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2 with binding energies at 1021.9 eV and 1044.9 eV were assigned to the characteristic peaks of Zn2+ in pure ZnO. For NiCo/ZnO-300 and NiCo/ZnO-400 catalysts, the Zn 2p signals positively shifted about 0.1–0.2 eV. The higher binding energy for Zn 2p signal compared to in pure ZnO sample demonstrated the electron-deficient state of Zn species due to the formation of Co(and/or Ni)-Zn interaction and thus the electron transfer from Zn to Co(and/or Ni) species. As a counterpart, the binding energy of Co 2p negatively shifted about 0.2 eV. However, this situation was exactly opposite for NiCo/ZnO-500 and NiCo/ZnO-600 catalysts. The Zn 2p signals negatively shifted about 0.1–0.3 eV and corresponding Co 2p positively shifted about 0.1–0.3 eV, which might be due to the high calcination temperature causing catalyst sintering, resulting in significant increase and agglomeration of metal and support particles, thus changing the trend of electron binding energy movement. Table 2 summarized the proportions of different Co and Ni species on the catalyst surface. From Table 2, the relative proportion of Co and Ni species in NiCo alloy increased from 40.2 % and 14.0 % to 44.5 % and 15.4 %, respectively, for NiCo/ZnO-300 and NiCo/ZnO-400 catalysts, indicating that the elevation of calcination temperature could promote the formation of NiCo alloy. Further elevating temperature to 500 °C and 600 °C, the relative proportion of Co and Ni species for NiCo/ZnO-500 and NiCo/ZnO-600 catalysts decreased remarkably to 21.6 %, 12.4 % and 18.7 %, 9.8 %, respectively, indicating that the too high temperature was not conducive to the formation of NiCo alloy due to the occurrence of the catalyst sintering. NiCo alloy may play a key role in the catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of LA. NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst with the highest proportion of NiCo alloy might exhibit good catalytic performance, which was confirmed by the following experimental content. Finally, the acid-base properties of the reduced NiCo/ZnOCT catalysts were determined by NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD technologies (see in Fig. 8 ). According to the previous reports [20,42], Lewis acidic sites (SLA) of the catalysts were crucial for the dehydration and cyclization process, while Lewis basic sites (SLB) might activate the carbonyl (C = O) group of LA to improve the GVL formation rate. ZnO, being an amphoteric oxide, possesses a large number of hydroxyl groups (-OH) on the surface of ZnO. These hydroxyl can release protons (H +) under certain conditions, thus exhibiting acidity. The oxygen atoms on the surface of ZnO can accept protons, thus displaying basicity. During the catalyst preparation process, with the increase of calcination temperature, the ability of hydroxyl groups and/or oxygen atoms on the surface of ZnO to release or accept protons changed, resulting in the changes in acidity and basicity [43]. From Fig. 8A, the catalysts exhibited two distinct NH3 desorption peaks, with the peak at 150–250 °C corresponding to the desorption of NH3 desorption from weakly SLA and the peak at 250–450 °C corresponding to the desorption of NH3 from moderately SLA. From Fig. 8B, the catalysts exhibited three distinct CO2 desorption peaks, with the peak at 50–150 °C corresponding to the desorption of CO2 from weakly SLB, the peak at 150–250 °C corresponding to the desorption of CO2 from moderately SLB and the peak at 300–400 °C corresponding to the desorption of CO2 from strongly SLB. Table 3 showed the total amount of SLA and SLB of catalysts. From Table 3, there were fewer SLA in the catalyst, mainly SLB. As the calcination temperature increases, the total amount of SLB showed a trend of first increasing and then decreasing. When elevating the calcination temperature from 300 °C to 400 °C, the total amount of SLB increased from 0.345 mmol/g to 0.376 mmol/g, which may be due to the enhanced effect of base properties caused by the interaction between Co, Ni and ZnO in NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst, as revealed by H2-TPR analysis. But further increasing calcination temperature to 500 °C and 600 °C, the total amount of SLB decreased significantly to 0.296 mmol/g and 0.243 mmol/g, respectively, which may be due to changes in the structure and acidic sites caused by catalyst sintering, as also revealed by SEM and TEM analysis. Based on SEM images, the reduced NiCo/ZnOCT catalysts with spherical flower-like particles (5–10 μm) composed of multiple thin-flakes inside were synthesized. Based on H2-TPR analysis, the strong metal-support interaction between Ni, Co and ZnO was established and strengthened with elevating calcination temperature. Based on XRD, TEM, XPS and CO2-TPD characterizations, the NiCo alloy and Lewis basic sites (SLB) in ZnO were formed and the proportion can be adjusted by changing calcination temperature. However, further increasing calcination temperature inevitably led to catalyst sintering, which resulted in larger particle size, lower specific surface area, and lower basicity of the NiCo/ZnOCT catalysts, as revealed by XRD, BET and CO2-TPD analysis. These situations may have a significant impact on the reaction performance for the hydrogenation of LA. Therefore, appropriate regulation of the NiCo/ZnO system was crucial for achieving optimal reaction performance. 3.3 Hydrogenation of LA 3.3.1 Catalyst screening The reaction performance of as-synthesized catalysts for LA hydrogenation was conducted, and the results were showed in Table 4 . GC–MS chromatogram showed that GVL was the main product and the by-products including ethyl levulinate (EL), 4-hydroxypentanoic acid ethyl ester (HAEE) and other unknown products (see Fig. S3). When no catalyst or only ZnO support was added, the hydrogenation reaction hardly occurred (Table 4, Entries 1–2), indicating the necessity of catalyst incorporation. When using NiCoOx/ZnO-300 as a catalyst, LA conversion was only 6 % and the yield of GVL was 5 % (Table 4, Entry 3), indicating that the oxidized samples exhibited minimal hydrogenation activity even under a hydrogen atmosphere. When the oxidized sample was reduced at 400 °C (Table 4, Entry 4), the yield of GVL was 89 %, but the yield of by-products increased to 11 %. The reason for this phenomenon may be that the lower calcination temperature led to weaker metal-support interaction, resulting in the formation of free active metals Co0 and/or Ni0, which compromised the selectivity of the catalyst. When the reduced NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst was used (Table 4, Entry 5), the full conversion of LA and 99 % yield of GVL was obtained. The excellent catalytic performance towards GVL synthesis was attributed to the synergistic effect between Ni, Co and ZnO due to strong metal-support interaction. To confirm the hypothesis, Co/ZnO and Ni/ZnO were used. Hydrogenation of LA using Co/ZnO gave 78 % yield of GVL, whereas only 24 % of GVL was formed when Ni/ZnO was used as a catalyst (Table 4, Entries 6–7), suggesting that Co was the main active metal. And simple mixing of Co/ZnO and Ni/ZnO (Table 4, Entry 8) led to a lower yield of GVL (81 %) but higher than either catalyst alone, which further illustrated the synergistic effect between Ni, Co and ZnO in NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst. According to the relative literature [44,45], the hydrogenation of carbonyl compounds can be promoted by dissociative hydrogen and Lewis base sites (SLB). In this work, Co was the main active metal to adsorb the dissociative hydrogen and the concentration of dissociative hydrogen was further increased due to the synergistic effect with Ni to form NiCo alloy, as evidenced by XRD and TEM analysis. Besides, SLB sites (ZnO) can activate C = O of LA, thus facilitating LA hydrogenation to GVL over NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst. When the reduced NiCo/ZnO-500 catalyst was used (Table 4, Entry 9), the conversion of LA decreased to 88 % and the yield of GVL decreased to 86 %. Further elevating the calcination temperature to 600 °C, hydrogenation of LA using NiCo/ZnO-600 catalyst (Table 4, Entry 10) gave only 74 % yield of GVL, indicating that the reaction performance of the catalysts gradually weakened with elevating calcination temperature over 400 °C. Based on the above characterization results, although higher calcination temperature can enhance the interaction between metal and support, they also inevitably caused catalyst sintering and the decrease in specific surface area, as revealed by SEM and BET analysis, greatly diminishing the reaction performance of the catalyst. In addition, to investigate the influence of catalyst morphology or structure on reaction performance, NiCo/ZnOamo-400 (IMP) and NiCo/ZnO-400 (IMP) catalysts were used for the LA hydrogenation reaction (see Table S1). When using commercial ZnO as a carrier, the NiCo/ZnOamo-400 (IMP) catalyst achieved a GVL yield of 75 %. When ZnO prepared by co-precipitation method was used as the carrier, the GVL yields were 90 % and 99 % for NiCo/ZnO-400 (IMP) and NiCo/ZnO-400, respectively, which indicated that the flower-like morphology of ZnO by co-precipitation method can promote the hydrogenation of LA. Finally, a comparative analysis was conducted with two highly performing catalysts reported in the literature (Table 4, Entries 11–12). For the hydrogenation of LA, noble metal Ru-based catalyst exhibit high activity at near room temperature. However, Palkovits et al. reported that Ru/C catalyst demonstrated lower LA activity (75.5 %) and GVL selectivity (81.0 %) at 130 °C in ethanol solvent system [46]. In this work, prepared Ru/C catalyst simply achieved 81 % conversion of LA and 75 % yield of GVL. In addition, a non-noble metal Cu/Ni/Mg/Al catalyst [29] exhibited 100 % conversion of LA and 92 % yield of GVL. Thus, the above results highlight the superior benefits of the NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst. 3.3.2 Catalyst performance with various reaction parameters The catalytic performance of the reduced NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst concerning reaction temperature was shown in Fig. 9 A. A gradual increase in LA conversion was observed with elevating reaction temperature from 80 °C to 100 °C, and the yield of GVL increased from 70 % to 99 % and then maintained with further increasing reaction temperature to 110 °C. Thus, 100 °C was considered the suitable reaction temperature. Regarding H2 pressure (Fig. 9B), the yield of GVL increased from 76 % to 99 % with H2 pressure was raised from 1 MPa to 2 MPa and well maintained when the pressure was further increased to 2.5 MPa, indicating that H2 pressure of 2 MPa was sufficient. The effect of catalyst dosages (Fig. 9C) on LA conversion and GVL yield was conducted and significant increase in GVL yield was achieved from 60 % to 99 % when catalyst dosages was increased from 30 mg to 100 mg. Further increasing the dosage to 120 mg did not significantly change the catalytic performance, indicating the catalyst dosages of 100 mg was appropriate. In addition, the effect of various solvents was also explored in Fig. 9D. Considering 1,4-dioxane was widely used in LA hydrogenation, it produced about 92 % yield of GVL. As for typical polar protic solvents, alcohols including ethanol, 2-propanol and n-butanol exhibited notable differences in LA hydrogenation to GVL. Specifically, 60 % and 84 % yield of GVL were obtained using n-butanol and 2-propanol as solvents, respectively. The highest 99 % yield was obtained when ethanol was used as a solvent. Thus, ethanol as a solvent was a good choice. To understand the function of ethanol for LA hydrogenation, the reaction was carried out at 100 °C under 2 MPa N2 for 6 h over NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst (Fig. S4). The conversion of LA was 100 % after 6 h, but the yield of target product GVL was only about 5 %, indicating that ethanol was not a good hydrogen source. Instead, 95 % yield of EL was obtained, thus the main role of ethanol was to form EL by the esterification with LA, which was different from the relative literature [47,48]. Based on the reaction results in Fig. 9D, it can be inferred that EL may have better reaction reactivity than LA. To confirm the assumption, LA and EL were employed simultaneously at 100 °C under 2 MPa H2 for 2 h (Table S2). It was observed that when LA was used, the yield of GVL was 64 %. However, when EL was used, the yield of GVL was 80 %. These results also indicated that the formation of EL can promote the hydrogenation reaction leading to GVL. 3.3.3 Reaction pathway Based on the above characterization and experimental results, a possible reaction pathway was proposed (Scheme 1 ). According the relative literature [20], the SLB sites of ZnO support can promote esterification reaction. Under the action of SLB sites (CO2-TPD) in ZnO support, LA firstly underwent esterification with ethanol solvent to form EL (Fig. S3), which was easier to hydrogenate than LA (Table S2). For the hydrogenation process, Co serves as the main active metal for adsorbing the dissociated hydrogen and the concentration of dissociative hydrogen was further increased due to the synergistic effect with Ni to form NiCo alloy. Then the formed NiCo alloy in NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst can efficiently promotes the dissociation and adsorption of hydrogen gas. Additionally, it has been confirmed that ZnO support can activate the C = O group. Thus, the obtained EL can be hydrogenated to produce HAEE. In addition, due to ZnO being an amphoteric oxide, a small amount of SLA sites (NH3-TPD) in the catalyst can promote HAEE further converting to the target product GVL. However, the relatively low content of SLA sites in NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst (Table 3) also effectively inhibited the generation of alpha-Angelica lactone intermediate product. Based on the above factors, the reduced NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance for LA hydrogenation to GVL. 3.3.4 Catalyst recyclability Catalyst recyclability was an important indicator for evaluating catalyst performance. Thus, the recyclability of the reduced NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst was presented for LA hydrogenation to GVL at 100 °C for 2 h under 2 MPa H2 (Fig. 10 ). After reaction, the catalyst was centrifuged and washed 3 times using ethanol before proceeding directly to the next reaction without undergoing activation. For each reaction cycle, it was observed that there was about 2 % of the mass of the catalyst. To compensate for the loss, the fresh catalyst was added. From Fig. 10, it can be seen that the catalyst maintained good activity for LA hydrogenation after being used six times, and the activity was slightly decreased after the seventh cycle. The Ni and Co contents in the fresh and spent catalysts were examined by ICP-AES analysis (Table S3). No detectable Ni and Co leaching was observed. In addition, XRD patterns (Fig. S5) of the fresh and spent catalysts showed that there was no significant change in the structure of the catalyst. The above results indicated that the reduced NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst has good stability. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of the reduced NiCo/ZnOCT (CT=300, 400, 500 and 600 °C) were synthesized by co-precipitation method. Based on SEM images, the reduced NiCo/ZnOCT catalysts possessed spherical flower-like particles (5–10 μm) composed of multiple thin-flakes inside. Based on H2-TPR analysis, the strong metal-support interaction between Ni, Co and ZnO was generated and strengthened with elevating calcination temperature. Furthermore, characterizations via XRD, TEM, XPS and CO2-TPD indicated that the formation of NiCo alloy and Lewis basic sites (SLB) in ZnO, with their proportion can be adjusted by changing calcination temperature. The experiment results showed that the formed NiCo alloy can increase the LA activity and selectivity towards GVL, while SLB in ZnO can activate the C = O group. Besides, it was found that ethanol solvent can combined with LA to form ethyl levulinate (EL) which was easier to be hydrogenated than LA. By this way, a good NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst was synthesized, achieving full conversion of LA and highest 99 % GVL yield at 100 °C and 2 MPa H2 for 5 h. Furthermore, this catalyst exhibited excellent stability, maintaining its performance after six reuse cycles. coredata.dc:description: The hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) represents a pivotal reaction, with its resultant product is widely used in solvents, fuels, pesticides, pharmaceuticals and other fields. The challenge associated with this process resides in achieving high selective generation of GVL. In this work, a spherical flower-like ZnO supported Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst (NiCo/ZnO) was prepared to facilitate the process of LA to GVL. The results showed that the NiCo alloy formed in the catalyst enhance both the hydrogenation activity of LA and the selectivity of GVL. Furthermore, the Lewis basic sites (SLB) in ZnO are instrumental in activating the C = O group. More importantly, it was found that the ethanol solvent can combine with LA to form ethyl levulinate (EL) which was more easily hydrogenated than LA. By regulating the appropriate calcination temperature, the proportions of NiCo alloy and SLB can be adjusted, and the NiCo/ZnO-400 catalyst with good performance was synthesized. Under the reaction condition of 100 °C and 2 MPa of H2 for 5 h, the LA was completely converted, yielding a remarkable GVL production of 99 %. The catalyst displayed good recyclability, maintaining its activity after 6 times without loss of activity, highlighting its potential for practical application in biomass conversion.
